Parable of Going to Sea to Get Sandalwood (22) Parable of Going to Sea to Get Sandalwood: In the past, the son of an elder went to sea to get sandalwood. After years of accumulation, he obtained a cart and brought it back home.

He went to the market to sell it, but because it was expensive, no one bought it. After many days, he was unable to sell it, and his mind became tired and distressed. Seeing that when people sold charcoal, they could sell it quickly, he thought:
It's not as good as burning it to make charcoal, which can be sold quickly.
So he burned it to make charcoal.
He went to the market to sell it, but did not get half the price of a cart of charcoal.

The foolish people in the world are also like this. They use countless skillful means and diligently practice to seek the fruit of Buddhahood, but because it is difficult to attain, they give rise to the thought of retreat, thinking it is not as good as giving rise to the resolve to seek the fruit of the Å›rÄvakas, quickly cutting off birth and death, and becoming arhats.

The Parable of the Thief Stealing Brocade to Wrap Rags (23) The Parable of the Thief Stealing Brocade to Wrap Rags: In the past, there was a thief who entered the house of a wealthy family and stole brocade. He then used it to wrap various old and worn-out rags and other belongings. He was laughed at by the wise.

The foolish people in the world are also like this. Having faith and entering the Buddha's teachings, they cultivate wholesome dharmas and various merits. But because of greed for profit, they break the pure precepts and various merits, and are ridiculed by the world in the same way.

The Parable of Planting Roasted Sesame Seeds (24) The Parable of Planting Roasted Sesame Seeds: In the past there was a foolish person who thought raw sesame seeds were not tasty. He roasted them and ate them, thinking they were delicious. He then thought:
It would be better to roast them and plant them, so that later I can get delicious ones.
He then roasted them and planted them, but they never grew.
People in the world are also like this. They think that the bodhisattvas' cultivation over many eons and their difficult practices are not pleasant. They then think:
It would be better to become an arhat and quickly end birth and death, which is much easier.
Later, they want to seek the fruit of Buddhahood but can never attain it, just like those burnt seeds that can never grow again. The foolish people in the world are also like this.

25. The Water and Fire Parable (25) The Water and Fire Parable: Once there was a person who needed to use fire and cold water. He then lit a fire and filled a water container with water, placing it on the fire. Later, when he wanted to get fire, the fire was completely extinguished, and when he wanted to get cold water, the water was also hot, losing both the fire and cold water.

People in the world are also like this. They enter the Buddha's teachings, leave the household life to seek the Way, and after leaving the household life, they still think of their wives, children, relatives, worldly matters, and the pleasures of the five desires.
For this reason, they lose the fire of merit and the water of upholding precepts. Those who think of desires are also like this.

The Parable of a Person Imitating the King's Twitching Eyes (26) The Parable of a Person Imitating the King's Twitching Eyes: Once there was a person who wanted to please the king. He asked others, How can I do that?
Someone said to him, If you want to please the king, you should imitate the king's appearance.
This person then went to the king's place later and saw the king's eyes twitching, so he imitated the king's twitching.
The king asked him, saying:
Are you sick?
Are you afflicted by wind?
Why are your eyes twitching?
That person replied to the king:
My eyes are not sick, nor am I afflicted by wind. I want to get close to the king. Seeing the king's eyes twitching, I am imitating the king.
Hearing these words, the king became greatly angry and immediately ordered people to inflict various harms on him and banish him from the country.
The people of the world are also like this. They want to get close to the Dharma King of the Buddha and seek his good Dharma to increase themselves.

Having gotten close to him, they do not understand that the Dharma King TathÄgata, for the sake of sentient beings, manifests various expedient means to show their shortcomings. Hearing his Dharma and seeing that some of the words and phrases are not correct, they then give rise to criticism and imitate what is not right.
For this reason, they will forever lose their wholesome [roots] in the Buddha's teachings and fall into the three evil destinies, just like King Hsiao.

The Parable of Treating a Whip Wound (27) The Parable of Treating a Whip Wound: In the past, a man was whipped by the king. After being whipped, he applied horse dung to it, wanting it to heal quickly.
A fool saw this and was delighted in his heart, saying:
I have definitely obtained this method of treating wounds.
He then returned home and told his son:
Whip my back, I have obtained a good method and now want to try it out.
The son whipped his back and applied horse dung to it, considering it a skillful method.
The people of the world are also like this. Hearing someone say that by cultivating impurity meditation, one can remove the wounds of the five aggregates, they then say:
I want to contemplate women's forms and the five desires.
Not seeing impurity, they are instead confused and deluded by female form, transmigrating through birth and death, falling into hell. The foolish people in the world are also like this.

The Parable of Trading One's Nose for a Wife (28) The Parable of Trading One's Nose for a Wife: In the past, there was a man whose wife was beautiful except for having an ugly nose. When he went out, he saw other women with beautiful faces and very nice noses, and he thought,
Why don't I cut off her nose and attach it to my wife's face? Wouldn't that be good?
So he cut off another woman's nose and brought it home. He urgently called his wife,
Come out quickly! I'll give you a nice nose.
When his wife came out, he cut off her nose and immediately attached the other nose to his wife's face, but it did not stick on and he lost her nose, causing his wife to suffer greatly.

The foolish people in the world are also like this. They hear that other old Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as have great fame and virtue, are respected by the people of the world, and obtain great benefits and support. They then think like this:
I am now no different from them.
They falsely claim to have virtue, and when they lose their benefits and also injure their practice,
it is like cutting off someone else's nose and only injuring themselves. The foolish people in the world are also like this.

The Parable of a Poor Man Burning Coarse Cloth (29) The Parable of a Poor Man Burning Coarse Cloth: In the past, there was a poor man who was destitute and impoverished. He worked for others and obtained coarse cloth, which he put on.
Someone saw him and said to him:
You are the son of an upright and noble family. Why do you wear this coarse and shabby cloth?
I will now teach you and make you obtain the finest clothes. You must follow my words and I will never deceive you.
The poor man was delighted and respectfully followed his advice. The man then lit a fire in front of them and said to the poor man:
Now you can take off your coarse hempen clothes and put them in the fire. In this burning place, I will make you obtain wonderful and precious garments.
The poor man then took off his clothes and put them in the fire. After they were burned, he searched in the fire for the precious garments but found nothing at all.

The people of the world are also like this. They cultivate various wholesome dharmas in their past lives and obtain this human body. They should protect it, advance their virtues, and cultivate their work. However, they are deceived by the evil and licentious women of non-Buddhist paths:

You should now believe my words and cultivate various ascetic practices. After throwing yourself off a cliff, into a fire, and abandoning this body, you will be reborn in the Brahma Heaven and experience long-lasting happiness.

They then use their words to abandon their lives. After death, they fall into hell and experience various sufferings. Having lost their human bodies, they obtain nothing, just like the poor man in this story.

30. Parable of the Sheep Herder (30) Parable of the Sheep Herder: In the past there was a man who was skilled at raising sheep. His sheep were very numerous, amounting to ten thousand. He was extremely stingy and would not use them externally.
At that time there was a person who was good at deception. He devised a plan to go and befriend him, saying:
I now want to be extremely close friends with you, to be as one body, no different.
I know that there is a good girl in that family. I will seek her for you to be your wife.
The sheep herder, upon hearing this, was delighted and gave him many sheep and various valuables.
That person said again:
Your wife has given birth to a daughter today.
The sheep herder had not yet seen his wife, but upon hearing that she had given birth, he was overjoyed and gave him more valuables.
That person later said to him:
Your son was born and has now died.
The shepherd, hearing these words, wept bitterly.

The people of the world are also like this. Having cultivated much learning, they hoard the Dharma for fame and profit, unwilling to teach and expound it for others. They are deceived by this defiled body, vainly hoping for worldly pleasures.
Like one's own wife and children deceiving one, losing wholesome dharmas, later losing one's life and wealth, one then grieves and suffers greatly, like the shepherd.

The Parable of Hiring a Potter (31) The Parable of Hiring a Potter: In the past, there was a Brahmin teacher who wanted to hold a great assembly and said to his disciple, I need pottery vessels for the assembly. You can hire a potter for me and go to the market to find one.
At that time, the disciple went to the potter's house.

At that time, there was a man whose donkey was carrying earthenware vessels to the market to sell. In a short while, the donkey broke all of them. Returning home, he cried and lamented in distress. The disciple saw this and asked him,
Why are you so sad and distressed like this?
That man replied,

I have been diligently accumulating for many years to finally complete these vessels. I went to the market to sell them, but this bad donkey broke all my vessels in a short while. That is why I am distressed.
At that time, the disciple, having seen and heard this, joyfully said,
This donkey is a fine thing. What has been made over a long time can be broken in a short while. I will now buy this donkey.
The potter joyfully sold it to him.
Riding it back home, the master asked,
Why didn't you bring the potter? What use is this donkey?
The disciple replied,
This donkey is better than the potter. In a short time, it can break the pottery that the potter has made for a long time.
At that time, the master said:
You are very foolish and lack wisdom!
This donkey can now just break things. Even if it were a hundred years old, it could not make even one.

People in the world are also like this. Even if they receive people's offerings for a thousand years, they have nothing to repay. They always cause harm and never benefit. People who are ungrateful are also like this.

The Parable of the Merchant Stealing Gold (32) The Parable of the Merchant Stealing Gold: In the past, there were two merchants who went on a business trip together. One sold genuine gold, and the second one sold cotton.

There was someone who bought genuine gold and burned it to test it. The second merchant then stole the burned gold from the other person and wrapped it with cotton. At that time, because the gold was hot, it burned the cotton to the end. The truth was revealed, and both things were lost.

Just as those non-Buddhists stole the Buddha's teachings and put them in their own teachings, falsely claiming them as their own and not the Buddha's teachings, for this reason the non-Buddhist scriptures were burned and destroyed and no longer circulated in the world, just like the incident of stealing gold is completely evident, it is also like this.

The parable of cutting down a tree to get fruit (33) The parable of cutting down a tree to get fruit, in the past there was a king, there was a good tree that was very tall and wide, about to bear excellent fruit that was fragrant and sweet.
At that time there was a person who came to the king, the king said to him:
This tree is about to bear delicious fruit, can you eat it?
He immediately replied to the king:
This tree is tall and wide, although I want to eat it, how can I get it?

He then cut down the tree hoping to get the fruit, but having nothing to gain he only exhausted himself in vain, later wanting to replant it, the tree had already withered and died and was completely unviable.

It is the same with people in the world. The TathÄgata, the Dharma King, has a tree of precepts that can produce excellent fruits. If one wishes to obtain the fruit and eat it, one should uphold the precepts and cultivate various merits. If one does not understand skillful means, one will instead violate the precepts, like cutting down a tree and wanting it to revive, which is absolutely impossible. A person who breaks the precepts is also like this.
The Parable of Sending Delicious Water (34) The Parable of Sending Delicious Water: In the past, there was a village five yojanas away from the royal city. In the village, there was delicious water.
The king ordered the villagers to always send the delicious water every day. The villagers were exhausted and wanted to move away from the village.
At that time, the village chief said to the people:
You should not leave!
I will tell the king on your behalf to change the five yojanas to three yojanas, so that you can come and go without being tired.
He went to tell the king, and the king changed it to three yojanas. When the people heard this, they were greatly delighted.
Someone said:
This is still the original five yojanas, nothing has changed.
Although they heard this, they still would not give up because they believed the king's words.

The people of the world are also like this. They practice the right Dharma to cross the five paths and head towards the city of nirvana, but their minds become weary and they want to give up, stuck in birth and death and unable to move forward.

The Dharma King Tathagata has great skillful means. He distinguishes the teaching of the One Vehicle into three. The followers of the Lesser Vehicle hear this and are delighted, thinking it is easy to practice. They cultivate goodness, progress in virtue, and seek to cross birth and death. Later, they hear people say that there are not three vehicles, that it is only one path.
They believe the Buddha's words and will not give up, just like the villagers in this story.

35. The Parable of the Jewel Chest and Mirror (35) The Parable of the Jewel Chest and Mirror: In the past, there was a poor man who was destitute and deeply in debt, unable to repay it, so he fled to an empty and desolate place.
He came across a chest filled with precious treasures, with a bright mirror placed on top of the treasures, covered with a lid.
When the poor man saw it, he was overjoyed and immediately opened it. Seeing the person in the mirror, he became frightened and said with his hands clasped in respect,
I thought the empty chest was completely empty, not knowing that there was you in the chest. Please do not be angry.

Ordinary people are also like this. They are impoverished by immeasurable afflictions and are bound by the creditors of birth and death, the demon king. Wishing to escape birth and death and enter the Buddha's teachings, they cultivate wholesome dharmas and create various merits.

It is like encountering a treasure chest, being confused by the mirror of the view of self, mistakenly seeing a self, and immediately becoming attached to it, thinking it is real. In this way, one falls and loses all merits, the dhyÄna concentrations, the factors of the path, the wholesome roots without outflows, and the fruits of the paths of the three vehicles, all lost.
It is the same for those who abandon the treasure chest and become attached to the view of self.

The Parable of the Five-Supernatural-Powers Sage's Eyes (36) The Parable of the Five-Supernatural-Powers Sage's Eyes: In the past, there was a person who entered the mountains to study the Way and attained the five supernatural powers of a sage. With his heavenly eye, he could see through the ground and all the various precious treasures in the hidden storehouses.
The king heard of this and was overjoyed. He said to his ministers:
How can I make this person always stay in my country and not go elsewhere?
Cause my treasury to obtain many precious treasures.
A foolish minister immediately went to him, gouged out the sage's two eyes, brought them back to the king, and said:
I have gouged out his eyes, so I can no longer send him away. He will always stay in this country.
The king said to the minister:
The reason I greedily wanted the sage to stay is because he could see all the hidden treasures in the ground. Now that you have destroyed his eyes, what use is he to me?

The people of the world are also like this. They see others practicing austerities in the mountains, forests, wilderness, and under trees, cultivating the four foundations of mindfulness and the contemplation of impurity, so they forcibly bring them back to their homes to make various offerings, destroying others' wholesome dharmas, causing their spiritual fruits to be unaccomplished, losing their spiritual eye, and missing out on the benefits, just like that foolish minister who pointlessly destroyed the other's eyes.
Parable 37: Killing a Herd of Cows Once there was a man who had 250 cows, always driving them to graze and feeding them according to the season.
At that time, a tiger ate one of the cows. The owner of the cows then thought:
Since one cow has already been lost and none are complete, what use are these cows?
They then drove them to a deep pit and a high cliff, pushed them into the pit, and killed them all.
Ordinary foolish people are also like this. They uphold the TathÄgata's complete precepts, but if they violate one precept, they do not feel ashamed or repent with a pure mind, and then think:
Since I have already broken one precept and am not complete, what is the use of upholding it?
They break everything and leave nothing, just like that foolish person who killed all the cows and left none behind.

The Parable of Drinking Water from a Wooden Tub (38) The Parable of Drinking Water from a Wooden Tub: Once there was a man who was thirsty from traveling. He saw clear flowing water in a wooden tub, went to drink it, and drank enough water. He then raised his hand and said to the wooden tub:
I have finished drinking, do not let the water come out again.
Although he said this, the water still flowed as before. He became angry and said:
I have already drunk and told you not to come, why did you come?
Some people saw this and said:
You are very foolish and lack wisdom!
Why didn't you go and say not to come?
They then pulled him back and led him to another place.

The people in the world are also like this. For the thirst of birth and death, they drink the salty water of the five desires. Having already been tired by the five desires, like having drunk enough, they say:
You forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches, do not come again to make me see them.
However, the five desires continue without interruption. Having seen them, they then become angry again:
Tell you to quickly disappear and not come again, why did you come to make me see you?
At that time, a wise person said to them:
If you want to get away from this, you should restrain your six senses and close your mind. If delusions do not arise, you will attain liberation.
Why must one not see and not allow to arise?
It is no different from the foolish person who drinks water.

The Parable of Seeing Others Plastering a House (39) The Parable of Seeing Others Plastering a House: In the past, a person went to someone else's house and saw that the walls and ground of the other person's house were plastered and leveled, clean and very nice. He then asked,
What is used to plaster it to make it so nice?
The host replied,
It is made by soaking rice husks in water until they are soft, mixing them with mud to plaster the walls, and that is why it is like this.
The foolish person then thought to himself,
If it is just rice husks, it is not as good as using rice to make it. The walls can be white and the mud can be level and nice.
He then used rice husks to mix with mud to plaster the walls, hoping to make them level, but instead they became even higher and lower, and the walls all cracked.
The rice husks were wasted and of no benefit, unlike the merit that can be obtained from giving alms.

Ordinary people are also like this. Hearing the sages expound the Dharma and cultivate various wholesome deeds, they can attain rebirth in the heavens and liberation upon leaving this body. They then kill themselves, hoping to attain rebirth in the heavens and liberation, but they vainly waste their lives and gain nothing, just like that foolish person.

The Parable of the Bald Man (40) The Parable of the Bald Man: Once there was a man whose head was hairless. In winter he was very cold and in summer he suffered from heat, and he was bitten by mosquitoes and horseflies, suffering day and night, which he found very painful.
There was a doctor with many medical skills. The bald man went to him and said:
I only wish that the great master would treat me.
At that time, the doctor was also bald. He then took off his hat and showed him, saying:
I also suffer from it and find it painful. If you want me to treat it and be able to cure it, you should first treat yourself and remove the ailment.

The people of the world are also like this. They are harmed by birth, old age, sickness, and death, and want to seek a place of eternal life and immortality. Hearing that there are Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmans, and other good doctors in the world who can cure various afflictions, they go to them and say:
Please remove this affliction of impermanence, birth and death, for me, and let me always dwell in peace and bliss, abiding for a long time without change.
Then the brÄhmans and others immediately reply:
We are also afflicted by this impermanence, birth, old age, sickness, and death. We have sought in various ways for a place of eternal existence but have never been able to find it.
If we could now make you attain it, we should have attained it ourselves first and then let you attain it as well.
It is like that bald man who tires himself in vain but cannot be cured.

41. The PiÅ›Äca Ghost Parable (41) The PiÅ›Äca Ghost Parable: In the past, there were two PiÅ›Äca ghosts who shared a box, a staff, and a shoe. The two ghosts argued over them, each wanting to get them. The two ghosts argued all day without being able to settle it.
At that time, a person came and saw them. He asked,
What is so special about this box, staff, and shoe?
Why are you two arguing and angry over them?
The two ghosts replied,
This box of ours can produce all kinds of clothing, food and drink, bedding, bedding supplies, and necessities, all coming out from it.
If we hold this staff, enemies will submit and dare not argue with us.
If we wear these shoes, we can make people fly without obstruction.
When this person heard this, he said to the ghosts,
You two go far away. I will fairly divide them for you.
The ghosts heard his words and immediately moved far away.
The man immediately grabbed his chest, took his staff, put on his sandals, and flew away. The two ghosts were startled and ended up with nothing.
The man said to the ghosts:
You two have been arguing over what I have already obtained and left. Now I make you argue over nothing more.
The piÅ›Äca is a metaphor for the various demons and non-Buddhists.
Giving is like a chest, from which the necessities of the five paths of humans and gods all come out.
Meditation is like a staff, which subdues the enemies of demons and the thieves of afflictions.
Upholding precepts is like sandals, which will surely lead one to the heavens.
The demons and non-Buddhists arguing over the chest is a metaphor for strongly seeking rewards in the contaminated [paths], ending up with nothing.
